questions.text: During a heated altercation in a public space, an individual is accused of physically assaulting another person, resulting in the victim sustaining a broken mandible. The incident, witnessed by several bystanders, prompts immediate police intervention. Given the severity of the injury and the circumstances surrounding the altercation, what action are the police most likely authorized to take against the accused individual?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Arrest without warrant

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The key fact to remember is that grievous hurt , such as a broken mandible, is a cognizable offense . This allows the police to arrest the accused without a warrant due to the serious nature of the injury.
  • ➤ grievous hurt
  • ➤ cognizable offense

questions.text: BNS (Bhartiya Nyaya Sanhita) is?
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Code for punishment

questions.text: During a late-night shift in a district hospital's emergency department, a medical officer is urgently called to attend to a patient with critical injuries from a hit-and-run accident. As the patient's condition deteriorates rapidly, the medical officer realizes the importance of recording the patient's account of the incident, suspecting it might be the patient's dying declaration. Given the urgency of the situation and the legal significance of the patient's statement, which of the following actions aligns best with the protocol for recording a dying declaration in India?

options.label: A
options.text: The medical officer must wait for the presence of the accused and their lawyer before recording the patient's statement.

options.label: B
options.text: The medical officer can record the patient's statement, but it is preferable for a magistrate to do so for it to be considered in court.

options.label: C
options.text: The medical officer is allowed to ask leading questions to quickly gather all necessary information from the patient.

options.label: D
options.text: If the patient unexpectedly recovers, their recorded statement will remain as the primary evidence in court proceedings.

questions.correct_answer: B. The medical officer can record the patient's statement, but it is preferable for a magistrate to do so for it to be considered in court.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) The medical officer can record the patient's statement, but it is preferable for a magistrate to do so for it to be considered in court.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A medical officer is allowed to record a dying declaration in urgent circumstances, though it is preferable for a magistrate to do so. The recorded statement is legally significant but must be taken without leading questions, and the presence of the accused or their lawyer is not required.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man was found deceased under suspicious circumstances in a rented apartment in Mumbai. The case has drawn significant media attention, and there is pressure on authorities to conduct a thorough investigation. According to the Indian legal process, which type of inquest will be done in India for such cases?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Police Inquest

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In India, the commonest inquest is police inquest. Other than police inquest, the other inquest is magistrate inquest which is done in few conditions like Dowry death, exhumation, and custodial deaths. Coroner’s inquest and medical examiner system are not done in India.

questions.text: During a complex murder trial, the defense attorney argues that the local court overseeing the case lacks the authority to sentence their client to the death penalty, should they be found guilty. As a medical professional called to serve as an expert witness on the psychological state of the defendant, you're asked to familiarize yourself with the judicial power of sentencing in India. Which of the courts listed below is not authorized to pass a death sentence under Indian law?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Magistrate court

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Additional session court can pass death sentence , but a sentence of death passed by it must be confirmed by the High Court .
  • • Option B.
  • • pass death sentence
  • • confirmed
  • • High Court
  • • Option C. Session court can pass death , but a sentence of death passed by it must be confirmed by the High Court .
  • • Option C.
  • • pass death
  • • confirmed
  • • High Court
  • • Please note that “ sessions ” and “ additional sessions ” courts have the same powers , whereas “ assistant sessions court ” is lower than sessions court .
  • • sessions
  • • additional sessions
  • • courts
  • • same powers
  • • assistant sessions court
  • • lower
  • • sessions court
  • • Option D. The High Court is usually located in the capital of every State and is the highest tribunal for the State . It may try any offence and pass any sentence authorized by law .
  • • Option D.
  • • located
  • • capital
  • • every State
  • • highest tribunal
  • • State
  • • try any offence
  • • pass any
  • • sentence
  • • law

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Indian Court System
  • ➤ Indian Court System
  • ➤ Ref: - Reddy 33/e. Pg 7
  • ➤ Ref: - Reddy 33/e. Pg 7

questions.text: Dr. Singh, a cardiologist in New Delhi, is under investigation after several complaints from patients regarding his prescription practices, which allegedly violate the nationally recognized medical code of ethics. He is accused of overprescribing medications in exchange for incentives from a pharmaceutical company. In the context of medical regulation in India, which authority(ies) is/are primarily responsible for issuing a formal warning to Dr. Singh?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) State Medical Council

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A . The Central Government typically does not get involved in issuing warnings for ethical violations at the level of individual medical practitioners.
  • • Option A
  • • Central Government
  • • does not
  • • issuing warnings for ethical violations
  • • Option C . While NMC is involved in drafting a general list of practices which can be considered unethical and lead to warning but they do not typically issue warning to individual doctors. It is issue by SMC
  • • Option C
  • • drafting a general list of practices
  • • unethical and lead to warning
  • • Option D . While the Medical Council of India (MCI) was replaced by the National Medical Commission (NMC) in 2019, sets and enforces ethical standards for all of India.
  • • Option D
  • • Medical Council of India
  • • replaced
  • • National Medical Commission

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The state medical council is responsible for the issuing a warning notice to a physician for violating the medical code of ethics .
  • ➤ state medical council
  • ➤ issuing a warning notice
  • ➤ physician
  • ➤ medical code of ethics
  • ➤ Ref : Reddy 33/e. p25
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Reddy 33/e. p25

questions.text: A neurosurgeon at a private hospital has a standing agreement with a referring primary care physician. For every patient referred to the neurosurgeon, the primary care physician receives a certain percentage of the surgical fee. This arrangement has come under scrutiny during a routine audit by the healthcare regulatory authority. What is this controversial practice called?

options.label: C
options.text: Filing an FIR against the patient for not paying the fee

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Dichotomy

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A . " Conduct money " - It is the money given or paid to a witness in civil cases to meet the expenses towards attending the court . In civil cases, conduct money is paid to the doctor at the time of serving the summons. If the money is not paid or the doctor feels that the sum paid is inadequate, he can inform the court accordingly.
  • • Option A
  • • Conduct money
  • • money given or paid to a witness in civil cases to meet the expenses towards attending the court
  • • Option C . Filing a "FIR" ( First Information Report ) against a patient for not paying a fee is a legal term related to law enforcement.
  • • Option C
  • • Filing a "FIR"
  • • First Information Report
  • • against
  • • patient for not paying a fee is a legal term
  • • Option D . " Res Ipsa loquitor " is a legal term used in tort law that applies when the cause of an injury is presumed to be negligence by the principle that certain events may not happen in the absence of negligence.
  • • Option D
  • • Res Ipsa loquitor
  • • legal term used in tort law that applies when the cause of an injury is presumed to be negligence

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dichotomy - is defined as Receiving or giving commission or other benefits to a professional colleague or chemist or dentist or manufacturer. It is a kind of PROFESSIONAL MISCONDUCT and can be punished by the State Medical Council. The punishment can be:
  • ➤ Receiving or giving commission or other benefits to a professional colleague or chemist or dentist or manufacturer.
  • ➤ PROFESSIONAL MISCONDUCT
  • ➤ Warning Suspension Penal erasure (professional death sentence).
  • ➤ Warning
  • ➤ Suspension
  • ➤ Penal erasure (professional death sentence).
  • ➤ Ref : Reddy 33/e. p646
  • ➤ Ref :
  • ➤ Reddy 33/e. p646

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy Gautam is accused of causing a grievous hurt to an elderly man in his neighborhood. The case of Gautam will be tried in a juvenile court which has a Juvenile justice board. Which of the following is true with respect to the composition of the juvenile justice board?

options.label: C
options.text: Judicial Magistrate of first class who must be a woman

questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A ) Metropolitan Magistrate or a Judicial Magistrate of First Class . The board will have the same powers as that of Metropolitan Magistrate / Judicial Magistrate of First Class , i.e. Imprisonment up to 3 years and fine up to 10,000 Rs .
  • • Option A
  • • Metropolitan Magistrate
  • • Judicial Magistrate
  • • First Class
  • • Metropolitan Magistrate
  • • Judicial Magistrate
  • • First Class
  • • Imprisonment
  • • 3 years
  • • fine up
  • • 10,000 Rs
  • • Two social workers (at least one woman). These social workers should have either experience of 7 years in child welfare activities OR a professional degree in child psychology , psychiatry , sociology , or law .
  • • Two social workers
  • • either experience
  • • 7 years
  • • child welfare activities
  • • professional degree
  • • child psychology
  • • psychiatry
  • • sociology
  • • law

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Juvenile Justice ( Care and Protection of Children ) Act, 2015 has replaced the Juvenile Justice ( Care and Protection of Children ) Act , 2000 .
  • ➤ Juvenile Justice
  • ➤ Care
  • ➤ Protection of Children
  • ➤ Act, 2015
  • ➤ Juvenile Justice
  • ➤ Care
  • ➤ Protection
  • ➤ Children
  • ➤ Act
  • ➤ 2000
  • ➤ The latest amendment is that the juveniles in conflict with Law in the age group of 16–18 , involved in Heinous Offenses , can also be tried as adults . The bill will allow a Juvenile Justice Board to preside over matters related to Juvenile offenses .
  • ➤ The latest amendment is that the juveniles in conflict with Law in the age group of 16–18 , involved in Heinous Offenses , can also be tried as adults .
  • ➤ The latest amendment is that the juveniles in conflict with Law in the age group of 16–18 , involved in Heinous Offenses , can also be tried as adults .
  • ➤ latest amendment
  • ➤ juveniles
  • ➤ conflict
  • ➤ Law
  • ➤ age group
  • ➤ 16–18
  • ➤ Heinous Offenses
  • ➤ adults
  • ➤ The bill will allow a Juvenile Justice Board to preside over matters related to Juvenile offenses .
  • ➤ The bill will allow a Juvenile Justice Board to preside over matters related to Juvenile offenses .
  • ➤ Juvenile Justice Board
  • ➤ Juvenile offenses
  • ➤ Ref: The Gazette of India, 12 Jan 2016
  • ➤ Ref: The Gazette of India, 12 Jan 2016

questions.text: At a district hospital, a forensic expert is called to review a case involving a 30-year-old woman who underwent an appendectomy. Post-surgery, she experienced severe abdominal pain and subsequent investigations revealed a surgical sponge left inside her abdomen. Due to this, she developed a severe infection leading to extended hospitalization. The woman has filed a lawsuit against the operating surgeon. In this case, which legal principle suggests that the burden of proof for demonstrating the absence of negligence rests with the doctor?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Res ipsa loquitor

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Mens rea : This term refers to the mental state of intending to commit a crime or knowing that one's action or lack of action would result in a crime. It is not directly applicable in the context of medical negligence.
  • • Option A. Mens rea
  • • mental state of intending to commit a crime
  • • Option C. Res judicata : This principle means that a case has already been judged and cannot be pursued further in court . It does not apply to the initial determination of negligence.
  • • Option C. Res judicata
  • • case has already been judged and cannot be pursued further in court
  • • Option D. Vicarious liability : This involves a party being held responsible for the actions of another , such as an employer for an employee’s actions. While relevant in some medical negligence cases, it does not shift the burden of proof regarding negligence.
  • • Option D. Vicarious liability
  • • party being held responsible for the actions of another

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ 'Res ipsa loquitur' in medical negligence cases , particularly in scenarios where the negligence is apparent and requires the defendant (usually the medical professional or institution) to prove the absence of negligence.
  • ➤ 'Res ipsa loquitur'
  • ➤ medical negligence cases
  • ➤ negligence is apparent and requires the defendant
  • ➤ Ref : Reddy 33/e. Pg 45
  • ➤ Ref :
  • ➤ Reddy 33/e. Pg 45

questions.text: In a legal case involving a patient's medical treatment, the court requires information about the patient's medical condition and treatment history. However, the treating physician is concerned about the ethical and legal aspects of disclosing patient information, which is typically confidential. Under which legal concept can professional secrecy be divulged in a court of law without violating ethical standards?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Privileged communications

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Privileged communication allows for the disclosure of confidential medical information when required by a court, without violating ethical standards. A court order takes precedence over the usual confidentiality protections in the physician-patient relationship.
  • ➤ Privileged communication

questions.text: In a community health center, a 13-year-old boy presents to a general practitioner with complaints of a sore throat. He has come to the clinic alone, without any adult accompanying him. The general practitioner is considering the appropriate legal course of action in this situation. What should the general practitioner legally do in this case?

options.label: B
options.text: Refuse to see him unless a responsible adult is present

options.label: C
options.text: Write to the parent asking them to come to the surgery

questions.correct_answer: A. Examine and prescribe as appropriate
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Examine and prescribe as appropriate.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option B. Refuse to see him unless a responsible adult is present: is not typically the best choice because doctors often prioritize the immediate health needs of the patient , especially if the patient is above the age of 12 and capable of understanding their condition.
  • • Option B.
  • • Refuse to see him unless a responsible adult is present:
  • • doctors often prioritize the immediate health needs of the patient
  • • Option C. Write to the parent asking them to come to the surgery: may cause delays in providing timely medical care to the 13-year-old patient. The presence of a guardian is not typically required if the patient is above 12 and capable of understanding their condition.
  • • Option C.
  • • Write to the parent asking them to come to the surgery:
  • • delays in providing timely medical care
  • • Option D. Examine but not prescribe: is not ideal because it may leave the patient without necessary treatment. It’s often better to examine and, if needed, prescribe treatment, especially if the patient is above 12 and capable of understanding their condition.
  • • Option D. Examine but not prescribe:
  • • it may leave the patient without necessary treatment.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Minimum age at which a person can give consent:
  • ➤ Minimum age at which a person can give consent:
  • ➤ Ref : Reddy 33/e. Pg 53
  • ➤ Ref :
  • ➤ Reddy 33/e. Pg 53

questions.text: During an autopsy conducted by a forensic expert at a medical college, the body of a 40-year-old man who died in a hospital is examined. The man was initially hospitalized following a car accident. The autopsy reveals that the man had a pre-existing medical condition that was exacerbated by a delayed surgery due to hospital administrative errors. Additionally, it is found that the man had not been wearing a seatbelt at the time of the accident. In this context, which type of negligence would involve the concept of 'contributory negligence' as a defense?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Civil negligence

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option B. Criminal negligence : This pertains to reckless disregard for the safety of others . Practically limited to cases in which the patient has died. Mostly associated with drunkenness or impaired efficiency due to the use of drugs by doctors. Doctor shows gross incompetency and inattention in the selection and application of remedies, undue interference by him or criminal indifference to the patient’s safety. Sec. 304-A IPC deals with criminal negligence. Contributory negligence is not a defense in criminal cases.
  • • Option B. Criminal negligence
  • • reckless disregard for the safety of others
  • • Sec. 304-A IPC
  • • Option C. Corporate negligence : This involves negligence by a corporation , like a hospital. It focuses on organizational failures rather than individual actions.
  • • Option C. Corporate negligence
  • • negligence by a corporation
  • • Option D. Composite negligence : This occurs when a patient suffers harm due to the negligence of two or more doctors . It involves multiple negligent parties, it does not specifically address the issue of the plaintiff's contributory negligence
  • • Option D. Composite negligence
  • • occurs when a patient suffers harm
  • • negligence of two or more doctors

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Contributory Negligence -
  • ➤ Contributory Negligence -
  • ➤ Contributory negligence is any unreasonable conduct, or absence of ordinary care on the part of the patient , or his personal attendant , which combined with the doctor's negligence , contributed to the injury complained of, as a direct, proximate cause and without which the injury would not have occurred.
  • ➤ unreasonable conduct, or absence of ordinary care
  • ➤ part of the patient
  • ➤ personal attendant
  • ➤ combined with the doctor's negligence
  • ➤ If the doctor and the patient are negligent at the same time, it is a good defense for the doctor. The doctor cannot plead contributory negligence, if he fails to give proper instructions.
  • ➤ Ref : Reddy 33/e. Pg 39-40
  • ➤ Ref :
  • ➤ Reddy 33/e. Pg 39-40

questions.text: A patient is brought into the emergency room after a severe car accident. The patient is unconscious and in critical condition, with multiple injuries. In this situation, the healthcare team may need to perform various surgical procedures, such as: Emergency surgery to stop internal bleeding. Orthopedic surgery to repair broken bones. Neurosurgery to relieve pressure on the brain. Plastic surgery to address facial injuries. Thoracic surgery to treat lung injuries. Given the urgency of the situation and the patient's inability to provide specific consent, the healthcare team may ask a family member for consent to perform any necessary surgeries to stabilize and treat the patient's injuries, without giving details on specific type of surgery. This is a type of?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Blanket consent

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Informed consent : Since detailed information on type of surgery is not provided to family member, it is not an informed consent
  • • Option A. Informed consent
  • • detailed information on type of surgery is not provided
  • • Option B. Implied consent : Since the permission for doing surgery is specifically taken , it is an expressed consent (not implied)
  • • Option B. Implied consent
  • • the permission for doing surgery is specifically taken
  • • Option D. Both B and C : This cannot be the answer as B choice is wrong.
  • • Option D. Both B and C

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Consent can be of two types based on how much information provided on how much information provided:
  • ➤ Ref : Reddy 33/e. Pg 51
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Reddy 33/e. Pg 51

questions.text: A patient undergoes abdominal surgery in a hospital. Postoperatively, the patient complains of severe pain and discomfort. Subsequent imaging reveals a pair of surgical scissors left inside the abdomen. The patient files a lawsuit against the hospital for medical negligence. In the legal proceedings, which doctrine is most applicable to this case, where the facts of the incident inherently suggest negligence without the need for extensive evidence?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Res ipsa loquitor

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Res integra - This term refers to a matter not previously decided by the courts (a case or a question that has not been examined or passed upon), not specifically relevant to the apparent negligence in this scenario.
  • • Option A. Res integra
  • • matter not previously decided by the courts
  • • Option B. Res gestae - Remarks made by the victim at the time of or immediately after the crime are admissible as evidence , e.g. statements made to people at the scene or to the doctor in hospital.
  • • Option B. Res gestae
  • • victim at the time of or immediately after the crime are admissible as evidence
  • • Option D. Res judicata - This refers to a matter that has been adjudicated by a competent court and therefore may not be pursued further by the same parties , not relevant in the initial stages of a negligence case i.e. A matter already adjudged and decided.
  • • Option D. Res judicata
  • • matter that has been adjudicated by a competent court and therefore may not be pursued further by the same parties

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ref : Reddy 33/e. Pg 38, 643
  • ➤ Ref :
  • ➤ Reddy 33/e. Pg 38, 643

questions.text: In the realm of medical practice, the principle of vicarious liability plays a crucial role in determining legal responsibility. Which of the following statements best exemplifies the concept of vicarious liability in cases of medical negligence?

options.label: A
options.text: Medical institutions can only be held responsible for the actions of their employed medical professionals if the institution had direct knowledge of the negligence

options.label: B
options.text: Vicarious liability does not apply when medical professionals commit gross negligence, as such actions are considered beyond the scope of their employment

options.label: C
options.text: Vicarious liability extends to situations where medical professionals are acting as independent contractors within a medical institution

options.label: D
options.text: Vicarious liability mandates that medical institutions are immune to legal action if the medical professional involved has a valid license to practice

questions.correct_answer: C. Vicarious liability extends to situations where medical professionals are acting as independent contractors within a medical institution
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Vicarious liability extends to situations where medical professionals, acting as independent contractors within a medical institution.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A . Medical institutions can only be held responsible for actions of their employed medical professionals if institution had direct knowledge of negligence.
  • • Option A
  • • Medical institutions can only be held responsible for actions
  • • if institution had direct knowledge of negligence.
  • • Vicarious liability is not dependent on institution's knowledge of negligence . Employer can be held responsible for the actions of their employees or agents (within the scope of their employment), regardless of the employer's knowledge of those actions.
  • • not dependent on institution's knowledge of negligence
  • • Option B . Vicarious liability does not apply when medical professionals commit gross negligence , as such actions are considered beyond the scope of their employment.
  • • Option B
  • • does not apply when medical professionals commit gross negligence
  • • Vicarious liability applies as long as negligent actions occurred within the scope of employment , irrespective of whether the negligence is considered "gross" or not. Nature of negligence, whether ordinary or gross, does not matter for applying vicarious liability.
  • • applies as long as negligent actions occurred within the scope
  • • of employment
  • • Option D. Vicarious liability mandates that medical institutions are immune to legal action if the medical professional involved had a valid license to practice .
  • • Option D.
  • • medical institutions are immune to legal action if the medical professional involved had a valid license to practice
  • • Possession of a valid license doesn't exempt medical institutions from vicarious liability . Even if a licensed professional commits negligence, the principle of vicarious liability can still hold the employer liable for the actions of their employee or agent.
  • • valid license doesn't exempt medical institutions from vicarious liability

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ In the context of medical negligence , vicarious liability means that a healthcare institution, such as a hospital or clinic, can be held legally responsible for the actions or omissions of its medical professionals (doctors, nurses, etc.) if those actions occurred within the scope of their employment. This holds true even if the institution itself did not directly contribute to the negligence. However, certain conditions, such as the actions occurring within the employment relationship and within the scope of duties, need to be satisfied for vicarious liability to apply.
  • ➤ medical negligence
  • ➤ vicarious liability means that a healthcare institution, such as a hospital or clinic, can be held legally responsible for the actions or omissions of its medical professionals
  • ➤ Ref : Reddy 33/e. Pg 47
  • ➤ Ref :
  • ➤ Reddy 33/e. Pg 47

questions.text: During a training session in forensic medicine, a resident learns about the importance of analyzing vitreous humor in determining the postmortem interval. Which constituent of vitreous humor is most helpful in accurately estimating the postmortem interval?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) K

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . Sodium levels change postmortem but are not as reliable as potassium for estimating time since death. sodium decreases by about 0.9 mmol/l/h after death.
  • • Option A
  • • sodium decreases
  • • about 0.9 mmol/l/h after death.
  • • Option C . Chlorides level decrease by rate of less than 1 mmol/l/h in postmortem period but are not as useful as potassium levels for this purpose.
  • • Option C
  • • Chlorides level
  • • decrease
  • • rate of less than 1 mmol/l/h
  • • Option D . The vitreous glucose usually falls after death and can reach zero within a few hours . A vitreous glucose of more than 11.1 mmol/l indicates diabetes , and less than 1.4 mmol/1 of hypoglycemia .
  • • Option D
  • • vitreous glucose
  • • falls
  • • after death
  • • reach zero
  • • few hours
  • • more than 11.1 mmol/l indicates diabetes
  • • less than 1.4 mmol/1 of hypoglycemia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A steady rise in the potassium values occur in the vitreous humour after death up to 100 hours .
  • ➤ steady
  • ➤ rise
  • ➤ potassium values
  • ➤ vitreous humour
  • ➤ after
  • ➤ death
  • ➤ 100 hours
  • ➤ Ref : Reddy 33/e. Pg 154
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Reddy 33/e. Pg 154

questions.text: Suspended animation may be seen with:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Electrocution

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Suspended animation, a state of temporary cessation of vital functions, may be seen in cases of electrocution, where immediate medical intervention can potentially reverse the effects and revive the person.

questions.text: Identify the image shown below and what does it indicate?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Death

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • A. Head injury and B. Eye injury : Incorrect . As explained above Kevorkian sign is seen after death when the blood pressure drops which is not a case in head injury or eye injury.
  • • Head injury
  • • Eye injury
  • • Incorrect

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Postmortem changes in the retina: The blood in retinal vessels appears fragmented or segmented ( cattle trucking or shunting ) within seconds to minutes after death and persists for about an hour (Kevorkian sign). This occurs all over the body due to loss of blood pressure , but it can be seen only in retina by an ophthalmoscope.
  • ➤ Postmortem changes in the retina:
  • ➤ fragmented
  • ➤ segmented
  • ➤ cattle trucking
  • ➤ shunting
  • ➤ after death
  • ➤ persists
  • ➤ about an hour
  • ➤ (Kevorkian sign).
  • ➤ loss of blood pressure
  • ➤ Ref : Reddy 33/e. Pg 152
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Reddy 33/e. Pg 152

questions.text: Dr. Nair, a medical officer, presents a challenging case to her peers for discussion. Dr. Nair is particularly interested in discussing a phenomenon, where the deceased's body temperature remains abnormally high after death. She asks her colleagues to identify which condition among the listed is least likely to be associated with this unusual postmortem finding.

options.label: A
options.text: Exposure to extreme heat leading to sunstroke

options.label: B
options.text: Fatal convulsions resulting from strychnine poisoning

options.label: C
options.text: Overwhelming systemic infection known as septicemia

options.label: D
options.text: Overdose of a central nervous system depressant, such as barbiturates

questions.correct_answer: D. Overdose of a central nervous system depressant, such as barbiturates
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Overdose of a central nervous system depressant, such as barbiturates

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Conditions such as sunstroke , strychnine poisoning , and septicemia can cause postmortem caloricity , where the body temperature remains high after death due to pre-death disturbances in heat regulation. In contrast, an overdose of CNS depressants like barbiturates leads to hypothermia , making it the least likely to cause postmortem caloricity.
  • ➤ sunstroke
  • ➤ strychnine poisoning
  • ➤ septicemia
  • ➤ postmortem caloricity
  • ➤ CNS depressants
  • ➤ hypothermia
  • ➤ least likely

questions.text: Rigor mortis be simulated by:
questions.explanation: Ans. A. Cadaveric spasm

questions.text: The medicolegal importance of the below finding noted in the eye is:

options.label: D
options.text: To determine position of the body

questions.correct_answer: A. To determine time since death
questions.explanation: Ans. A) To determine time since death.

questions.text: Correct order of putrefaction?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Brain, Heart, Uterus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Students should memorize the correct order of putrefaction: brain decays first , followed by heart , and the uterus decays last .
  • ➤ brain decays first
  • ➤ heart
  • ➤ uterus decays last

questions.text: A person in a village sees a dead body floating in a nearby pond. He informs the police and the dead body is brought for post mortem examination. What is the likely place where postmortem staining will be seen?

options.label: B
options.text: In hands and feet in a glove and stocking pattern

options.label: C
options.text: On the dorsal aspect of the body, except back of chest and buttocks

options.label: D
options.text: Over face, neck, front of upper part of chest, upper and lower limbs.

questions.correct_answer: D. Over face, neck, front of upper part of chest, upper and lower limbs.
questions.explanation: Ans. D.

questions.text: Honey comb liver is seen in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Putrefaction

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Honeycomb liver is a characteristic finding in putrefaction due to gas formation within liver tissue as part of the decomposition process.
  • ➤ Honeycomb liver
  • ➤ putrefaction

questions.text: Chicken fat appearance is seen in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Postmortem thrombus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The chicken fat appearance is seen in postmortem thrombi , where blood separates into distinct layers after death, creating a pale fibrin layer above and a red cell layer below.
  • ➤ chicken fat appearance
  • ➤ postmortem thrombi

questions.text: Time since death can be known by all of the following except?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Cadaveric spasm

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understand that cadaveric spasm occurs immediately and does not progress, so it cannot be used to estimate time since death, unlike algor mortis, rigor mortis, and livor mortis.
  • ➤ cadaveric spasm

questions.text: Postmortem caloricity is seen in all except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Barbiturate poisoning

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Postmortem caloricity, where the body temperature remains high after death, does not occur in barbiturate poisoning but may be observed in conditions like tetanus, strychnine poisoning, and septicaemia.

questions.text: Colour change in Putrefaction occurs due to which pigment?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The greenish discoloration observed in putrefaction is due to the formation of sulphmethemoglobin, which results from the reaction between hydrogen sulfide produced by bacteria and hemoglobin in the body.

questions.text: During a forensic pathology rotation, a medical resident is tasked with confirming the presence of hemoglobin in a blood sample from an old crime scene. The sample is degraded, and the resident must choose a test that yields specific microscopic findings to ensure the accuracy of the result. Which test should the resident utilize to observe the characteristic pink feathery crystals that confirm the presence of hemoglobin?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Takayama test

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option B. Hemin (Teichmann’s) test
  • • Option B. Hemin (Teichmann’s) test
  • • Reagent: NaCl + acetic acid
  • • NaCl + acetic acid
  • • Brownish-black rhombic crystals of hematin chloride
  • • Brownish-black rhombic crystals
  • • Negative in old stains or washed or treated with chemicals
  • • Negative
  • • old stains
  • • Option C. Barberio’s test -
  • • Option C. Barberio’s test -
  • • Reagent: Picric Acid .
  • • Picric Acid
  • • Component of semen detected: Spermine (secreted from prostate gland)
  • • Spermine
  • • Shape of crystals: Yellow needle shaped crystals of spermine picrate.
  • • Yellow needle shaped crystals
  • • Option D. Xanthoproteic test -
  • • Option D. Xanthoproteic test -
  • • The xanthoproteic reaction is a method that can be used to detect the presence of protein soluble in a solution , using concentrated nitric acid . The test gives a positive result in amino acids carrying aromatic groups (phenylalanine, tyrosine, and tryptophan) and forms a yellow-colored product known as Xantho protein.
  • • detect the presence of protein soluble in a solution
  • • concentrated nitric acid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Microchemical tests for Blood: Teichmann’s and Takayama test (Both are confirmatory tests)
  • ➤ Microchemical tests for Blood:
  • ➤ Teichmann’s - Brownish-black rhombic crystals of hematin chloride Takayama test - Pink feathery crystals of hemochromogen (reduced alkaline hematin)
  • ➤ Teichmann’s - Brownish-black rhombic crystals of hematin chloride
  • ➤ Brownish-black rhombic crystals
  • ➤ Takayama test - Pink feathery crystals of hemochromogen (reduced alkaline hematin)
  • ➤ Pink feathery crystals
  • ➤ Microchemical tests for Semen: Florence and Barberio test (Both are presumptive tests)
  • ➤ Microchemical tests for Semen:
  • ➤ Florence test—For choline (dark brown rhombic crystals) Barberio test— detects spermine (yellow needle-shaped rhombic crystals)
  • ➤ Florence test—For choline (dark brown rhombic crystals)
  • ➤ choline
  • ➤ Barberio test— detects spermine (yellow needle-shaped rhombic crystals)
  • ➤ spermine
  • ➤ Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 451; Pics from Book “Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology” by Gautam Biswas- Chapter Seminal Stains and Other Biological Samples
  • ➤ Ref:
  • ➤ Reddy 33/e. Pg 451; Pics from Book “Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology” by Gautam Biswas- Chapter Seminal Stains and Other Biological Samples

questions.text: A rape victim is examined in a hospital and a specimen from her vagina is subjected to staining by 10% HCl, potassium iodide, iodine and water. Dark brown needle-shaped crystals appear immediately. Which test was done?
questions.explanation: Ans. B. Florence test

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman is involved in a custody dispute and undergoes a forensic evaluation to establish the paternity of her child. The forensic scientist plans to use a bodily fluid for ABO blood typing, as the child is suspected to have inherited the secretor status from the parents. Which of the following bodily fluids is least likely to be suitable for ABO blood group determination in secretors?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Cerebrospinal Fluid (CSF).

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Tears - Secretors can have ABO antigens present in their tears .
  • • Option A. Tears
  • • present in their tears
  • • Option B. Saliva - A common sample used for ABO typing in secretors as it often contains blood group antigens.
  • • Option B. Saliva
  • • contains blood group antigens.
  • • Option C. Semen - Like saliva, semen can also be used for ABO blood group determination in secretors.
  • • Option C. Semen
  • • used for ABO blood group

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In secretors, ABO blood group antigens can be identified in various bodily fluids such as sweat, saliva, semen, urine, feaces, nasal secretions and tears , but not typically in cerebrospinal fluid.
  • ➤ bodily fluids such as sweat, saliva, semen, urine, feaces, nasal secretions and tears

References:

  • ↳ Reference - Reddy 33/e. Pg 455

questions.text: A man is caught peeping into the bathroom of a girl’s hostel and trying to watch the female inhabitant’s bathe. This sexual perversion is defined as:
questions.explanation: Ans. D) Voyeurism

questions.text: Knock out drop is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Chloral hydrate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chloral hydrate is known as the "knockout drop" due to its historical use in incapacitating individuals by inducing unconsciousness.
  • ➤ Chloral hydrate
  • ➤ "knockout drop"

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman is brought to the hospital by emergency medical services after being found unconscious in a park. She is unresponsive to verbal stimuli and is breathing very shallowly. Friends who were with her mention that she had been using drugs at a party earlier. Her breathing rate is 6 breaths per minute, and her pupils are constricted. Her skin is pale, and she feels cool to the touch. Which of the following substances is most likely responsible for her presentation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Opioid

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . Alcohol : Alcohol is also a CNS depressant, but the depressive effects are less severe as compared to opium poisoning . The pupils are usually dilated in alcohol poisoning; they become contracted only in late stages of alcohol poisoning.
  • • Option A
  • • Alcohol
  • • CNS depressant, but the depressive effects are less severe as compared to opium poisoning
  • • Option B . Cocaine : It is a stimulant, not a depressant. So, the effects will be opposite. Cocaine poisoning will have dilated pupils. Breathing is rapid and shallow in cocaine but slow and shallow in opium poisoning. Also instead of unconsciousness, the person will be usually in heightened alertness.
  • • Option B
  • • Cocaine
  • • stimulant, not a depressant.
  • • Option D . Methaphmetamine : It is also a stimulant drug , and will have features somewhat similar to cocaine.
  • • Option D
  • • Methaphmetamine
  • • stimulant drug

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Opioid Poisoning - sign and symptoms
  • ➤ Opioid Poisoning - sign and symptoms
  • ➤ Ref : Reddy 33/e. Pg 585
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Reddy 33/e. Pg 585

questions.text: A 28-year-old male is brought to the emergency department with agitation, dilated pupils, and tachycardia. He appears restless and paranoid, and he is sweating profusely. His blood pressure is elevated. What is the likely cause of these symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Acute Cocaine poisoning

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acute cocaine poisoning presents with sympathomimetic symptoms such as agitation, dilated pupils, tachycardia, elevated blood pressure , and sweating , making it the most likely cause in this scenario.
  • ➤ Acute cocaine poisoning
  • ➤ sympathomimetic symptoms
  • ➤ agitation, dilated pupils, tachycardia, elevated blood pressure
  • ➤ sweating

questions.text: A medical officer is evaluating a case involving a 45-year-old factory worker who was admitted to the hospital with severe abdominal pain and signs of renal failure. The patient's medical history and employment in a facility that uses mercury in its processes raise suspicion of heavy metal poisoning. During the autopsy, the medical officer focuses on the kidneys to determine the specific site of damage caused by the suspected mercury poisoning. Which part of the kidneys is predominantly affected by mercury exposure?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Proximal Convoluted Tubule (PCT)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B . Distal Convoluted Tubule (DCT): Less affected by mercury.
  • • Option B
  • • Distal Convoluted Tubule
  • • Less affected by mercury.
  • • Option C . Collecting Duct : Not the primary site of mercury -induced damage.
  • • Option C
  • • Collecting Duct
  • • Not the primary site of mercury
  • • Option D . Loop of Henle : Also, less involved in mercury toxicity .
  • • Option D
  • • Loop of Henle
  • • less involved in mercury toxicity

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Specific nephrotoxic effects of Poisons
  • ➤ Specific nephrotoxic effects of Poisons
  • ➤ Nephrotoxic Poisons - Arsenic , mercury , oxalic acid, carbolic acid , CCl4, cantharides, turpentine, thallium, alphos and zinc phosphide. Parenchymatous degenerative changes are seen in metal and cantharidin poisoning . Necrosis of proximal convoluted tubules (PCT) is observed in mercuric chloride , phenol, lysol and CCl4 poisoning.
  • ➤ Nephrotoxic Poisons - Arsenic , mercury , oxalic acid, carbolic acid , CCl4, cantharides, turpentine, thallium, alphos and zinc phosphide.
  • ➤ Nephrotoxic Poisons
  • ➤ Arsenic
  • ➤ mercury
  • ➤ carbolic acid
  • ➤ Parenchymatous degenerative changes are seen in metal and cantharidin poisoning .
  • ➤ Parenchymatous degenerative
  • ➤ metal and cantharidin poisoning
  • ➤ Necrosis of proximal convoluted tubules (PCT) is observed in mercuric chloride , phenol, lysol and CCl4 poisoning.
  • ➤ Necrosis of proximal convoluted tubules
  • ➤ mercuric chloride
  • ➤ Ref : Reddy 33/e. Pg 624
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Reddy 33/e. Pg 624

questions.text: A welder presents to the emergency department with fever, chills, headache, fatigue, and muscle aches after working with galvanized steel for several hours. The place of work is poorly ventillated. On physical examination, his vital signs are stable, and there are no specific findings on examination. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient's symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Metal Fume Fever

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Metal fume fever is an acute, self-limiting condition caused by inhalation of metal fumes, particularly zinc oxide from galvanized steel. The symptoms mimic flu or malaria, including fever, chills, and muscle aches, and typically resolve within 24 to 48 hours.
  • ➤ Metal fume fever
  • ➤ zinc oxide

questions.text: Arsenic is not found in which organs?
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Brain

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient presents with complaints of pain, numbness, and darkening of the lower extremities. Physical examination reveals gangrene in the feet and lower legs. The patient reports a history of residing in an area with known arsenic-contaminated drinking water. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for the patient's presentation?
questions.explanation: Ans. B. Blackfoot disease

questions.text: The drumstick shape in the image shown below helps to determine:
questions.explanation: Ans. B. Sex

questions.text: Which of the following feature is not related to the mandible of male in comparison to females?
questions.correct_answer: A. Angle of ramus- More obtuse
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Angle of ramus- More obtuse

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The angle of the ramus is less obtuse in males compared to females, resulting in a more angular appearance of the male mandible. This contrasts with other features such as a larger condyle, prominent mental tubercles, and greater symphyseal height, all of which are more pronounced in males
  • ➤ angle of the ramus

questions.text: A forensic anthropologist is examining a set of skeletal remains discovered at an archaeological site. The mandible is relatively well preserved. The focus is on determining the sex of the individual based on the mandible. Which of the following features will be found in male mandible as compared to female mandible?

options.label: A
options.text: Square Chin, less obtuse angle of mandible, greater body height at symphysis, greater breadth of ascending ramus

options.label: B
options.text: Round Chin, less obtuse angle of mandible, greater body height at symphysis, greater breadth of ascending ramus

options.label: C
options.text: Square Chin, more obtuse angle of mandible, greater body height at symphysis, greater breadth of ascending ramus

options.label: D
options.text: Square Chin, less obtuse angle of mandible, smaller body height at symphysis, greater breadth of ascending ramus

questions.correct_answer: A. Square Chin, less obtuse angle of mandible, greater body height at symphysis, greater breadth of ascending ramus
questions.explanation: Ans. A. Square Chin, less obtuse angle of mandible, greater body height at symphysis, greater breadth of ascending ramus

questions.text: A person is accused of committing Rape. He claims to be adolescent. He is brought to the government hospital for age estimation to determine if he should be sent to juvenile home or an adult jail. The X-ray image of the pelvis is shown below. What is the age?
questions.explanation: Ans. C. 17-18 years

questions.text: Cephalic Index is:
questions.correct_answer: C. Ratio of A and B
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Ratio of A and B

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Cephalic Index is the ratio of the maximum breadth to the maximum length of the skull , used primarily for racial classification in anthropology.
  • ➤ Cephalic Index
  • ➤ maximum breadth to the maximum length of the skull

questions.text: Best bone for sex determination:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Pelvis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The pelvis is the best bone for sex determination, with an accuracy of up to 95% , as it exhibits clear anatomical differences between males and females.
  • ➤ pelvis
  • ➤ 95%
  • ➤ Note:
  • ➤ Note:

questions.text: Run Amok is caused by?
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Cannabis

questions.text: A Casualty medical officer is called to assess a patient who has ingested a toxic substance. During the assessment, the medical officer observes that the patient's urine has turned green. This unusual symptom raises concerns about the specific toxic substance involved. Which toxic substance is most likely responsible for the green-colored urine seen in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Phenol

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . Lead : Lead poisoning usually lead to symptoms like abdominal pain, anemia , and neurological changes .
  • • Option A
  • • Lead
  • • symptoms like abdominal pain, anemia
  • • neurological changes
  • • Option C . Organophosphorus: Organophosphorus compounds, primarily affecting the nervous system .
  • • Option C
  • • Organophosphorus:
  • • affecting the nervous system
  • • Option D . Cyanide: Cyanide poisoning, characterized by severe systemic effects such as respiratory failure and cardiac arrest
  • • Option D
  • • Cyanide:
  • • severe systemic effects
  • • respiratory failure
  • • cardiac arrest

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Green-colored urine as a potential indicator of phenol ingestion in cases of poisoning.
  • ➤ Green-colored urine
  • ➤ indicator of phenol ingestion
  • ➤ Some important Pointers related to Phenol Poisoning -
  • ➤ Some important Pointers related to Phenol Poisoning -
  • ➤ Postmortem Findings - External : Grayish or brownish corrosions at the angle of the mouth, chin, front of the body , arms and hands with phenolic odor. Putrefaction is retarded. Internal - Corrosion of the GIT mucosa , and laryngeal and pulmonary edema. Stomach: Marked corrosion of gastric mucosa and swelling of mucosal folds with coagulated grayish or brownish silvery mucus on it; Intervening normal mucosal folds appear dark red in color; Hardening of the stomach wall—leathery Stomach. Vomitus and gastric lavage collection show partially detached gastric mucosa . Kidneys: Hemorrhagic nephritis. Medico-legal Aspects - It is used for suicidal purposes ; Accidental poisoning may occur ; Phenol is rarely used for homicidal poisoning because of its odor and taste . Sometimes, it is used as an abortifacient.
  • ➤ Postmortem Findings - External : Grayish or brownish corrosions at the angle of the mouth, chin, front of the body , arms and hands with phenolic odor. Putrefaction is retarded. Internal - Corrosion of the GIT mucosa , and laryngeal and pulmonary edema. Stomach: Marked corrosion of gastric mucosa and swelling of mucosal folds with coagulated grayish or brownish silvery mucus on it; Intervening normal mucosal folds appear dark red in color; Hardening of the stomach wall—leathery Stomach. Vomitus and gastric lavage collection show partially detached gastric mucosa . Kidneys: Hemorrhagic nephritis.
  • ➤ Postmortem Findings -
  • ➤ External : Grayish or brownish corrosions at the angle of the mouth, chin, front of the body , arms and hands with phenolic odor. Putrefaction is retarded. Internal - Corrosion of the GIT mucosa , and laryngeal and pulmonary edema. Stomach: Marked corrosion of gastric mucosa and swelling of mucosal folds with coagulated grayish or brownish silvery mucus on it; Intervening normal mucosal folds appear dark red in color; Hardening of the stomach wall—leathery Stomach. Vomitus and gastric lavage collection show partially detached gastric mucosa . Kidneys: Hemorrhagic nephritis.
  • ➤ External : Grayish or brownish corrosions at the angle of the mouth, chin, front of the body , arms and hands with phenolic odor. Putrefaction is retarded.
  • ➤ External
  • ➤ Grayish or brownish corrosions
  • ➤ angle of the mouth, chin, front of the body
  • ➤ Internal - Corrosion of the GIT mucosa , and laryngeal and pulmonary edema. Stomach: Marked corrosion of gastric mucosa and swelling of mucosal folds with coagulated grayish or brownish silvery mucus on it; Intervening normal mucosal folds appear dark red in color; Hardening of the stomach wall—leathery Stomach. Vomitus and gastric lavage collection show partially detached gastric mucosa . Kidneys: Hemorrhagic nephritis.
  • ➤ Internal
  • ➤ Corrosion of the GIT mucosa , and laryngeal and pulmonary edema. Stomach: Marked corrosion of gastric mucosa and swelling of mucosal folds with coagulated grayish or brownish silvery mucus on it; Intervening normal mucosal folds appear dark red in color; Hardening of the stomach wall—leathery Stomach. Vomitus and gastric lavage collection show partially detached gastric mucosa . Kidneys: Hemorrhagic nephritis.
  • ➤ Corrosion of the GIT mucosa , and laryngeal and pulmonary edema.
  • ➤ Corrosion of the GIT mucosa
  • ➤ Stomach: Marked corrosion of gastric mucosa and swelling of mucosal folds with coagulated grayish or brownish silvery mucus on it; Intervening normal mucosal folds appear dark red in color; Hardening of the stomach wall—leathery Stomach.
  • ➤ Vomitus and gastric lavage collection show partially detached gastric mucosa .
  • ➤ Vomitus and gastric lavage collection
  • ➤ detached gastric mucosa
  • ➤ Kidneys: Hemorrhagic nephritis.
  • ➤ Medico-legal Aspects - It is used for suicidal purposes ; Accidental poisoning may occur ; Phenol is rarely used for homicidal poisoning because of its odor and taste . Sometimes, it is used as an abortifacient.

  • ➤ Accidental poisoning may occur

questions.text: An addict develops delusion, misleading hallucination of sight and hearing, and the feeling of creeping things of 'grains of sand' on the skin. He is addicted to?
questions.explanation: Ans. A. Cocaine
